Award.AbstractNarration:
Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution (WHOI) is awarded funding to support NSF peer-reviewed scientific research aboard R/V Knorr in CY 2012. In CY 2012 R/V Knorr will remain in the Atlantic Ocean fulfilling research requirements for NSF, ONR,and NASA. Research programs will include an ONR two-ship operation off Greenland. Mooring work will be conducted from R/V Knorr as well as studies in the biochemistry, including water sampling and sediment trap recoveries, geochemistry, studies on the Mid Atlantic Ridge, and acoustical research. Line W and joint NASA/NSF projects will be performed off R/V Knorr in the Atlantic Ocean. ROV Jason operations will be carried out on R/V Knorr at the Mid Atlantic Ridge, concluding with Knorr transiting to a shipyard for a regulatory dry-docking. This is year-one of a five-year cooperative agreement, and negotiations will be made yearly since the level of funding is dependent on the number of days at service in support of NSF funded research programs.


Technical and Intellectual Merit
These peer-reviewed projects have been rigorously evaluated for scientific and intellectual merit as an integral part of the NSF grant review and award process. The competitive nature of the award granting process ensures a very high level of intellectual merit. Knowledge gained and the discoveries made by the research programs supported by R/V Knorr will enhance understanding of the oceans and address a broad range of important scientific questions. The goal of this proposal is to provide funding support to safely and productively operate and maintain R/V Knorr in 2012 and to ensure it is maintained to support its planned life-cycle. This support is an essential prerequisite for safe and successful scientific missions.

Broad Impact Statement
WHOI research vessels provide at-sea laboratories necessary to effectively and safely take science to sea. This community includes senior oceanographic scientists, post-doctoral and doctoral students, graduate and undergrad students as well as engineers, technicians, and teachers. These intellectual endeavors have broadened our understanding and have spurred on new questions and scientific theory. Research supported by R/V Knorr next year will be important in understanding the Earth's climate and how it changes over time. In 2012 R/V Knorr will perform biogeochemical research by collecting water samples and conducting sediment traps in the Atlantic Ocean. Geochemical experiments will take place on the Mid Atlantic Ridge. Line W project and other mooring deployments and retrievals will also take place in the Atlantic from R/V Knorr in 2012. Joint NASA/NSF experiments will take place from R/V Knorr east of the Mid-Atlantic Ridge. Jason operations and acoustical experiments, using autonomous hydrophones, will also take place from R/V Knorr in 2012. R/V Knorr will end 2012 in a regularly scheduled dry-dock period either in an east coast shipyard or aboard, depending on 2013 scheduling needs. Educational and outreach programs such as Dive & Discover http://science.whoi.edu/DiveDiscover, NSF's COSEE Center, Ridge 2000, and Women Exploring the Ocean will be featured on these cruises. All of these intellectual endeavors will continue to broaden our understanding of the oceans, stimulate new questions, and confirm scientific theory for years to come, benefiting society at large.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcome Report for AWARD #OCE-1214207 WHOI Project 814207SP WHOI R/V Knorr Operations Cooperative Agreement: 04/01/2012 - 03/31/2017

Project Outcome and Findings Addressing Intellectual Merit and Broader Impacts:

 

This grant provided the funds to operate R/V Knorr for all NSF sponsored ship time from 2012 through 2014. R/V Knorr averaged approximately 12 voyages per year with an annual average of 238 days of operation during this period.  R/V Knorr contributed many special advances in oceanographic explorations of the world’s oceans between 2012 and 2014.

 

R/V Knorr provided unique capabilities to science over its history. It was the only ship in the world modified to deploy the 150 foot long core system. Also, the system to over-board the US GEOTRACES System was first developed and deployed on R/V Knorr.

 

NSF funded operations for Dr. Herbert in November 2013 to study high wind gas exchanges in the North Atlantic provided just the environment the research team was searching for. Winds were in excess of 60 knots and seas were enormous.

NSF expeditions for Drs. Lee and Pickart (OSNAP Program), in the North Atlantic and Davis Strait were supported from R/V Knorr during this period. These voyages helped science understand the variability of fluxes connecting the Arctic and Atlantic Oceans and the dynamics of shelf-basin exchange and the deep western boundary current in the Irminger Sea.

 

While conducting operations off South Africa in 2013 the NSF sponsored scientist Dr. Beal reported: “Objectives were to recover an array of thirteen moorings, occupy forty CTD/LADCP stations, and gather one continuous underway ADCP section across the Agulhas Current. The skill and willingness of the officers and crew contributed immensely to the achievement of our objectives. We recovered every instrument of every mooring and collected 17 extra CTD stations.”  This is the special legacy of R/V Knorr and all who served in her.

 

NSF supported science was conducted off of R/V Knorr from 2012 to 2014 along the entire length of the Mid-Atlantic Ridge. In 2012 Dr. Langmuir researched Mid-Atlantic segmentation. R/V Knorr continued sailing northward after that voyage to conduct NSF supported studies for Dr. Bidle. Research was to elucidate the molecular, ecological, and biogeochemical links between virus infection of coccolithophores and the global cycles of carbon and sulfur. Satellite (MODIS Aqua) signatures were used to inform the science team of the path. The scientific objectives were to transect the Northeast Atlantic (NEA) spring bloom (Azores to Iceland). NSF supported Dr. Luther in late 2012 to operate from Ponta Delgada, Azores to Charleston, SC collecting focused flow water samples from 3 known hot hydrothermal vent locations, using the remotely operated underwater vehicle Jason, on the Mid Atlantic Ridge.

 

In 2013 the southern portion of the Mid-Atlantic Ridge was explored for NSF funded research. Drs. Smith and Schouten collected regional multibeam bathymetry, gravity, and magnetic data. High-resolution multibeam, bathymetry, magnetic, CTD and optical sensor data were collected in critical locations from the autonomous underwater vehicle (AUV) Sentry, and photographs from the WHOI Tow Camera.  They also had an extensive dredging program.  Working north up the Mid Atlantic Ridge, Dr. Kujawinski followed with NSF research of the faults along the ridge.

 

Ocean Observatory Initiatives were supported in all three years of R/V Knorr’s last period of service to science.  NSF funded work at Line W for Dr. Toole also took place in 2014. NSF funded time was provided on R/V Knorr in 2013 for the National Deep Submergence Facility to tested their new Jason winch. Other customers such as the Office of Naval Research (Nordic Sea in 2014 and unmanned surface vessel operations in 2013) and NASA (SPURS Program) operated from R/V Knorr during this period.  NOAA (PMEL) also funded science on R/V Knorr for their air sampling program. Funding for the NASA work and NOAA work on R/V Tioga were passed-through to WHOI through this NSF Grant.

 

Research findings published from the cruises will advance understanding of the world’s oceans and this ecosystem. Real-time images and live conversations were broadcasted from these voyages into classrooms of the USA.  Knowledge gained and the discoveries made by the research programs supported by R/V Knorr enhanced the understanding of the oceans and addressed a broad range of important questions in all the scientific disciplines. These broader impacts were achieved through the operational support funding provided from this grant. These intellectual endeavors broaden the understanding of the oceans, spur new questions, and confirm scientific theory, benefiting society at large. R/V Knorr ended its service to the US academic fleet in late 2014. In early 2016, R/V Knorr was transferred to Mexico and is still operational and serving the Mexican Navy as the RIO TECOLUTLA BI-09.
